messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using PHP and the Laravel 11.x (laravel/framework ^11.28) framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. In `app/Http/Controllers/Admin/PostController.php`, I found that `App\\Http\\Controllers\\Admin\\PostController` is implemented to process HTTP requests. To determine the full path with the correct prefix and the acceptable HTTP methods, I found the necessary information in other files.

I'll provide you with the contents of all related files, and your task is to determine and output:

- The full HTTP request path for the endpoint, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}).
- Whether all HTTP methods are acceptable, this will override the results for other HTTP methods.
- Whether the HEAD method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the POST method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the OPTIONS method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the TRACE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the GET method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PUT method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the DELETE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PATCH method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.

You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
Full HTTP request path:
- /admin/posts/{post}

All HTTP methods accepted (i.e. Route::any)?:
- false

Acceptable methods (based on the code):
- HEAD: false
- POST: false
- OPTIONS: false
- TRACE: false
- GET: true
- PUT: true
- DELETE: true
- PATCH: true

Explanation
- routes/admin.php contains Route::resource('posts', PostController::class). A resource route for "posts" creates the standard resource URIs. The item-level URI produced by that resource is /posts/{post}; because the application uses route names like 'admin.posts.edit' in the controller redirects, the admin routes file is clearly loaded with an "admin." name prefix and (as is typical) an /admin URL prefix. That yields /admin/posts and /admin/posts/{post} as the full paths.
- Route::resource defines the following methods for the item path (/posts/{post}):
  - GET    -> show (GET /posts/{post})
  - PUT    -> update (PUT /posts/{post})
  - PATCH  -> update (PATCH /posts/{post})
  - DELETE -> destroy (DELETE /posts/{post})
  These are the methods that apply to /admin/posts/{post}, so I marked GET, PUT, PATCH and DELETE as true.
- POST is used by the collection path (/admin/posts) for store, so POST is false for the item path.
- I did not mark HEAD, OPTIONS or TRACE as acceptable because the route declarations in the provided code do not explicitly register HEAD, OPTIONS or TRACE handlers. The instructions asked to base acceptability on the code (route declarations) rather than on runtime/framework behavior or assumptions (for example, implicit HEAD handling by the framework), so those are false.
- "All methods" is false because the code does not use Route::any or equivalent to accept every method.
